claim: Skin cancer kills the most women in the U.S..

supporting.text: According to the American Cancer Society, lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among women in the U.S., not skin cancer.

attacks.text: According to the American Cancer Society, lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death among women in the U.S., not skin cancer.
Skin cancer mortality rates are rising significantly in recent years, potentially overtaking lung cancer in some demographics.
The American Cancer Society's data is based on comprehensive national statistics and remains the most reliable source for such claims.
Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, has a high mortality rate among younger women compared to other cancers.
While melanoma is deadly, its overall incidence and mortality are still lower than lung cancer across all age groups of women.

supporting.text: The CDC reports that heart disease is the number one cause of death for women in the U.S., surpassing all cancers combined.

attacks.text: The CDC reports that heart disease is the number one cause of death for women in the U.S., surpassing all cancers combined.
Skin cancer, while deadly, accounts for a smaller proportion of cancer deaths compared to other types like breast or lung cancer in women.
Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, has been increasing in incidence and can be highly lethal if not detected early.
Early detection and treatment of melanoma significantly reduce mortality rates, making it less deadly than other cancers with lower survival rates.

supporting.text: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, has a lower mortality rate compared to other cancers like breast or colorectal cancer in women.

attacks.text: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, has a lower mortality rate compared to other cancers like breast or colorectal cancer in women.
While melanoma may have a lower mortality rate, non-melanoma skin cancers (e.g., basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma) are more common and can also be fatal if untreated.
Non-melanoma skin cancers are rarely fatal due to their slow progression and high treatability when detected early.
Skin cancer incidence is rising rapidly due to increased UV exposure, which could shift mortality statistics in the future.
Improved public awareness and early detection methods are likely to mitigate any potential rise in skin cancer mortality rates.

supporting.text: Statistical data from the National Cancer Institute shows that skin cancer deaths in women are significantly fewer than deaths from other major cancers.

attacks.text: Statistical data from the National Cancer Institute shows that skin cancer deaths in women are significantly fewer than deaths from other major cancers.
The claim may be referring to melanoma, a specific aggressive form of skin cancer, which has high mortality rates in certain demographics.
Even melanoma accounts for only about 1% of skin cancer cases and is not the leading cause of cancer death among women in the U.S.
Skin cancer prevention campaigns might lead to overestimation of its mortality impact compared to less-publicized cancers.
Public awareness does not change actual mortality statistics, which still show lower skin cancer deaths compared to breast or lung cancer.
